awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  City-scale flood mapping using real-time sensor data
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses major fundamental knowledge gaps underpinning the ability to create accurate flood maps. This proposal will advance new knowledge on the use of advanced analytics for the estimation of floods, thus transforming the tools available to respond and plan for flooding. The working hypothesis of this proposal is that building-scale flood detection will be achieved through a combination of existing sensors and advanced analytics. This SBIR project will research and develop data-driven flood maps to support targeted flood response and long-term infrastructure planning. Using advanced analytics, existing sensor data will be spatially distributed to create real-time flood maps. The method will be validated using a highly dense sensor network in the Great Lakes region. The technical results of this project will yield unprecedented insights and measurements of uncertainty related to flood estimation at urban scales. The resulting real-time flood maps will allow stormwater managers to stay ahead of resident complaints, while saving lives and property by sending their crews to the most important locations. Improved flood maps will also allow stormwater managers to maximize the impact of long-term infrastructure investments.

The project's goal is to make all communities resilient to floods and climate change. To that end, this proposal will show how advanced analytics, driven by wireless sensing, will transform the ability of first responders to save lives, while helping stormwater managers maximize long-term infrastructure investments. The key innovation of this proposal is a data methodology, which will convert raw, spatially distributed sensor data into actionable, real-time flood maps. This data-driven technique will enable the first of its kind tool to detect floods at the scale of individual buildings, without requiring a sensor at every location.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Flooding is a devastating natural disaster, inflicting substantial damage, disruption, and even loss of life across communities nationwide. The escalating frequency and intensity of floods underscore the urgent need for innovative solutions to mitigate their impact. This project directly addresses this critical challenge by exploring a new system that empowers city managers to detect and respond to floods in real-time, bolstering their preparedness and resilience.

From a scientific standpoint, the project yielded significant advancements in the realm of flood monitoring and prediction. The accuracy of wireless flood detection sensors was rigorously validated, ensuring real-time and precise tracking of water levels. This real-time data stream serves as the foundation for generating dynamic flood maps that evolve in tandem with the unfolding flood event. Furthermore, the project team developed and tested a methodology to predict flood extents beyond the immediate vicinity of the sensors. This predictive capability provides a more holistic and comprehensive understanding of the flood's potential reach, enabling officials to anticipate areas at risk and take preemptive action. 

The broader impacts of this project resonate far beyond the scientific community, extending to the heart of communities grappling with the threat of flooding. By equipping cities with faster, more accurate flood detection and mapping tools, the outcomes empower officials to make well-informed decisions, deploy resources strategically, and implement protective measures in a timely manner. This translates to reduced property damage, minimized disruption to critical infrastructure, and ultimately, enhanced community safety. Beyond immediate disaster response, this technology fosters long-term community resilience by enabling better preparedness, planning, and adaptation to the growing challenges posed by flooding in an era of climate change. The outcomes of the project prioritized community safety and well-being while laying the foundation for municipal adaptation and resilience.


 

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Brandon P Wong
